filters.implementations

Class WelchMethodFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • filters.Filter
      • filters.implementations.WelchMethodFilter

  • public class WelchMethodFilter
extends Filter
    Welch method is a method to computes a special kind of periodogram averaged by time to reduce variance and therfore noise. Multiple window functions are provided to compute the periodogram
    Author:
    knoodrake

    • Method Detail

      • compute

        public static double[][] compute(double[][] data,
                 double fs,
                 int lfq,
                 int hfq,
                 int segLen,
                 boolean useSquareWindow,
                 boolean logYScale)
        Computes the periodogram of given signal with welch method
        Parameters:
        data - The original data, index 0 is X, time, and index 1 is amplitude
        fs - Sampling rate
        lfq - Lower frequency (in Hz) to show up
        hfq - Higher frequency (in Hz) to show up
        segLen - desired window length
        useSquareWindow - if true, uses square window instead of Hann
        logYScale - if true, amplitude is expressed in dB
        Returns:
        the periodogram plot data

      • compute

        public static double[][] compute(double[][] data,
                 int segmentLength,
                 double fs,
                 double freqLowerLimit,
                 double freqUpperLimit,
                 Window win,
                 java.lang.Boolean logYScale)
        Computes the periodogram of given signal with welch method
        Parameters:
        data - The original data, index 0 is X, time, and index 1 is amplitude
        segmentLength - Length of the data chuncks in samples
        fs - Sample rate
        freqLowerLimit - Lower frequency (in Hz) to show up
        freqUpperLimit - Higher frequency (in Hz) to show up
        win - the Window function used
        logYScale - If true, magnitude is expressed in a dB scale
        Returns:
        the periodogram plot data
        See Also:
        #compute(double[][], double, int, int)
